turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Emona.
turn.1: What is certain about the stones that were used to demarcate the city of Emona from the city of Aquileia?
turn.2: Because similar stones were only used to demarcate two communities belonging to the same Roman province and because it is not disputed that Aquileia belonged to Roman Italy, this means that both towns belonged to Italy and that Emona was never part of Illyricum (or, later, of the province of Pannonia).
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The architect Jože Plečnik redesigned the remains of the Roman walls: he cut two new passages to create a link to Snežnik Street () and Murnik Street (), and behind the walls he arranged a park displaying architectural elements from Antiquity, with a stone monument collection in the Emona city gate.
turn.5: What other things did he do to the city?
turn.6: Above the passageway to Murnik Street he set up a pyramid, which he covered with turf.
turn.7: What happened to the city after he redesigned it?
turn.8: After the Second World War, attempts were made to embed references to Emona grid into modern Ljubljana, with the Roman forum becoming part of the Ferant Park apartment blocks and an echo of the rotunda located along Slovenia Street ().
turn.9: Did the city ever change its name?
turn.10: There was a Christian bishopric named Aemona, whose bishop Maximus participated in the Council of Aquileia, 381, which condemned Arianism.
turn.12: After the destruction of Aemona in the 7th century, the bishop's seat was transferred to Novigrad ().
